We ask the S. A. C. to set a definite
date for the elections in each activity during the first two weeks of April and to
require that, as we suggested this week,
budgets for 1933-34 be submitted first to
the Student Activities Council and then
to the faculty committee before the end
of the third week in April. The percentage of each activity fee collected
should be definitely decided upon, however, before the budgets are called for
and brought up for approval by the faculty committee in April.

As we pointed out previously, we are
in accord with the belief that the S. A.
C. fee should be scaled down and eventually abolished entirely. With this in
mind we have drawn up this schedule for
appropriations to campus activities, giving
the S. A. C. 26% of the total amount.
Within a few years a fund could be collected so that a certain percentage could
be given to each activity. Eventually, if
the plan is successful, activities will be
placed on their own feet.

With the aid of Pi Delta Epsilon, Varsity Seals in the future will be awarded
to those connected with publications on
the basis of actual work done and not on
years of residence of the staffs. Inasmuch as the Seal is to undergraduate nonathletic activity leaders what the varsity
letter "H" is to outstanding athletes, the
plan of keeping a record of the date of

and business managers of work done by

of those eligible for award.
The editors and business managers of
the publications already members of the
honor group, it should be an easy task
to draw up suitable budgets for the newspaper, magazine, and yearbook on the basis of the data available on printing and
engraving costs.
We congratulate Pi Delta Epsilon on
its recent move and urge the movement's
support by Student Activities Council,
Omicron Delta Kappa, faculty committee
on student affairs, and the general staffs
of the publications.

Another Suggestion
THE RECEPTION with which our
editorials in the past two issues, dealing
with the rearrangement of the apportionment schedule for the various campus activities, has met is deeply appreciated by
this paper. We feel that what we are
pleading for is something of importance
to the entire University and is indubitably
a needed change in a worn-out system.
We call upon the Student Activities
Council and the faculty committee on
student affairs to consider, at once, the
S. A. C. distribution percentage plan
suggested by us Tuesday. It is agreed by
those concerned that apathy,.on the parts
of activity heads in the past has been the
chief obstacle to a more detailed consideration of budgets and appropriations.
Cooperation in the matter of submitting
budgets has been almost lacking between
the heads of the campus organizations

By PHILIP HAMBURGER, --

According to a professor at the
University of Alabama, the decrease in the average size of the
family is due to the multiplication
of luxuries and the decline of muscular exertion. The professor also
claimed in his recent address that
large families are advantageous in
that they keep people too busy for
much mischief and may produce
healthier and less spoiled children.

Three days before the Barnstormers' production is a bad time

at the present time, the many acCharles Davis is particularly busy

Davis, a senior in the college, entered Hopkins from the Marston
School in Ruxton. In his first year
he played football and lacrosse, and
,vas a member of the Barnstormers.
In his second year he made the Hullabaloo staff, continuing to play lacrosse. In his junior year he was
a member of the Dance Committee,
the Cotillion Board, the Barnstormers, the Hullabaloo and the lacrosse
squad. Today, he is the business
manager of the Hullabaloo and the
Barnstormers and president of Pi
Delta Epsilon, the honorary journalistic fraternity. He is also a member of the June Week Committee,
and of Omicron Delta Kappa, not
to forget Scabbard and Blade.
Phew!

Although the freshman class at
the University of Maryland has to
share part of the expense as a result of a recent escapade, nevertheless they are not so perturbed since
they "got the best" of the sophs,
anyway. It seems that the frosh
painted the following legend on one
of the campus buildings: "The
Frosh are supreme." During the
night the sophs added the word
"idiots". This action resulted in the
We Make a Point Clear
decision of the Student Council comWE WISH to make it clear that we pelling
the sophs to share in the exare not asking the undergraduates who
pense.
have paid their student

activities fee to
pay an additional sum for their subscription to THE NEWS-LETTER.
We are
asking only those scholarship students
who are not required to pay the tendollar fee and the graduate students and
faculty members who receive the paper
to pay for their subscription.
We take this opportunity to thank those
who have answered our plea for financial
support of this paper. It is encouraging
to note that there are some faculty members and graduate students who are interested in the publication. We hope that
those who have as yet not paid will do
so in the near future.
In all fairness, holders of scholarships,
who are not required to pay the ten-dollar
student activity fee, should willingly pay
the subscription price for this paper. Following the move made by The Black and
Blue Jay, we are willing to reduce the
cost, for these students, to $1.75.

"Furthermore," he continued, "I
feel that a return to freshman regulations would be a most potent
improvement on the Hopkins campus. I don't believe in horseplay,
but something is needed to consolidate and group the classes.
"I frankly believe," Charlie coneluded "That campus politics is a
very natural thing, and that without them much interest would be
lost. Of course, when they are not
played fairly, that's another matter."
It was lunch time, and as both
campus leaders and reporters must
eat, the the interview was over.

To the Editor, THE NEWS-LETTER:
When I first appeared on the
Hopkins campus, I was told That
I must pay the sum of $2.00, as
freshman class- dues, to the treasurer of the Student Activities
Council, or something like that.
After having parted myself and my
pocketbook from the filthy lucre, I
went my way merrily, expecting
that it had been contributed to a
good cause and expecting to get
something out of it. Of course,
I was looking forward to having a
dance or two out of the payment,
and perhaps a banquet thrown in.
When I learned that my expectations were not to be fulfilled to the
greatest extent; when I was informed that we Frosh got A banquet and only A banquet, I tried to
reconcile myself to this fact .. . but
when I learned that we must pay
about $2.00 for admittance to THE
banquet . . .
A FRESHMAN.

WHAT?

Architecture?
Kenneth Reid, managing editor
of the architectural publication,
"Pencil Points," writes:"The successful architect needs not only
an instinctive feeling for design
and a technical skill in construction, but also a complete cultural
background. Architecture requires long training, intensive
concentration, a keen mind."

UNION BUS TERMINAL

How to keep silt and sand from clogging telephone cable ducts was one problem put up to
engineers at Bell Telephone Laboratories. No
known method of joining sections of vitrified clay
conduit effected a seepage-tight joint.
With scientific thoroughness, telephone men
made many tests under service conditions. They
devised a bandage of cheese-cloth, waterproof
paper and mortar. Easily made and applied, this
mortar bandage is tight against silt and sand. It
prevents clogging, greatly simplifies the installation
of new telephone cables and the removal of old ones.
Through solving such interesting problems,
Bell System men work steadily nearer to their goal
— telephone service of highest possible efficiency.

FIRST MEETING
OF ICE HOCKEY
SQUAD TODAY
Group To Discuss Current
Plans At 12:20 In
Latrobe Hall
IS AGAIN MEMBER
OF LOCAL LEAGUE
Entire Varsity From Last
Year Again Available
For Duty
Ice hockey plans for the coming
season at the Johns Hopkins will
be discussed today at the first organized meeting of the squad, to be
held at 12:20 in Room 120, Latrobe Hall. All members of the
team, both veterans and new candidates, are requested to be present.
Hopkins has entered the local ice
hockey league again, along with the
University of Maryland, Baltimore
Athletic Club, Mount Washington,
and Green Spring Valley. Walbrook, champions of the circuit last
year, will not defend its laurels.
Therefore, a wide-open battle is expected to develop among the contenders for possession of the title.

Veterans Form Powerful Nucleus
For This Year's Squad;
Successful Season Seen
After two weeks of diligent practice at the Knights of Columbus
pool, the Johns Hopkins University
swimming team will have its first
time trials this afternoon. The
trials will be held in the 50,
100, and 220-yard free style; the
100-yard breast stroke and 100yard back stroke and the fancy dive.
Several of the distances are shortened because of the lack of practice.
A successful season is anticipated as there is a wealth of
veteran material back from last
year's team, forming a powerful
nucleus for the present squad.
Record Breakers To Swim
The outlook in fancy diving is exceedingly bright as Captain William
Reid, indoor and outdoor South Atlantc diving champion, will again
compete for the University. Frank
Levi and Charles Bahlke, members
of last year's record-breaking relay,
will form the nucleus for this year's
quartet. Material for the breast
stroke is also abundant with Eddie
Sadtler and Ted Stern, who have
both broken former University
breast-stroke records, available for
the coming season. Nicholas Camara-Peon, a co-holder of the Hopkins backstroke record, and Ernie
Hanhart, last year's captain, are
other former performers who will
be with the team this year.
In addition to these, Gordon,
Bishop, Davis, and McConnell, who
have had previous experience, are
members of the present squad.

Although the Black and Blue did
not finish very high in last season's
race, it gained much needed experience which should prove extremely
valuable. The team probably will
receive its stiffest competition from
Maryland and Green Spring Valley.
The Jays are well fortified in the
matter of seasoned skaters. Miller,
Cohen, Nickel, Scheid, Corckran,
and Turnbull, the six regulars of

JAY CAGERS
TO HOLD WORKOUTS
AT LOYOLA COLLEGE

Decide Definitely To Practice
And Play On Evergreen Court
After a week of steady practice,
staged temporarily at the Gilman
School gymnasium, the Johns Hopkins basketball team has made definite arrangements to make use of
the Loyola College gymnasium at
Evergreen for its practice sessions
and games during the 1932-1933
basketball season.
The Blue Jay cagers have been
holding workouts daily in which all
candidates have been receiving opportunities to show their playing
ability to Coach Darley.
Veterans Return

Among those showing promise at
the Black and Blue basketball drills
are Williamson, Lester and George
Margolis, Siverd, Yearley, Palitz,
Rapport, and Merriken.
The veterans who are back again
this season are Captain Don Kelly,
Caleb Kelly, Herb Camitta, Chancellor and Wulff.
The squad is still very small,
however, and all students interested
in playing basketball are urged to
report for practice.

(Continued from Page 1, Col. 6)
required to turn over to Pi Delta
Epsilon by Marih 22 the names of
nominees for the board of sontrol
posts for 1933-34. These men will
be considered at a meeting of the
honorary fraternity on March 24
and their merits will be openely discussed by the publication heads present. Should there be doubt as to
the capability of any nominee to
handle the position for which he is
nominated, it was said, the board
of control of the particular publication will be asked to reconsider the
candidate before elections are held
some time during the first two weeks
of April. It was pointed out that
an effort is to be made to weed out
those men who seek office for purely political reasons.
To Control Varsity Seal Awards

Holding to the belief that in the
past publications men have been
awarded Varsity Seals despite the
fact that they have failed to actually meet the requirement of three
years of work on the staff, Pi Delta
Epsilon will record the date of election to any staff of business and editorial candidates to THE NEWSLETTER, The Black and Blue Jay,
and The Hullabaloo, and will record any comments by publication
heads on the work done by staff
members. On the basis of this information Pi Delta Epsilon will recommend or reject eligibles for the
Varsity Seal award. In this way,
members said, those who do not deserve Seals will not be awarded
them.
A recommendation will be made
to the publications here to issue official identification cards to its staff
members and to include space on
these cards for the recording of the
date of election to the staff.
Tentative Date For Election

A tentative date, April 13, has
been set for the public annual initiation of men into the honorary fraternity. This date was chosen, it
was announced, because by that time
all editors and business managers
for 1933-34 will be chosen. The
Student Activities Council is to set
dates for all campus elections in the
first two weeks of April. It was said
that the heads of the three publications and outstanding members of
the staffs of the newspaper, magazine, and yearbook will be eligible
for election into Pi Delta Epsilon,
which has 40 chapters in colleges
throughout the United States.
At present there are eight men
in the Hopkins chapter, which was
reorganized in May, 1931, fife years
after its disbandment at Homewood. They are Charles Davis,
president; Morton Gutkin, secretary; Maurice Chassin, treasurer;
Hyman Levin, E. Gordon Biggs,
Gordon Green, Haskell Milestone,
and Morton Katz. They were
elected into the journalistic fraternity last April. Membership to the
J. H. U. chapter is restricted to
those who have been actively conhected with either THE NEWS-LETTER, The Black and Blue Jay, and
Dr. Broadus
The Hullabaloo.
Mitchell, associate professor of political economy, is an honorary
member of the organization.

Noted Editor

After leaving the ministry several years ago, Mr. Thomas founded
and became the editor of The World
Tomorrow. He has also been editor
of The Nation. At present he is
contributing editor to The World
Tomorrow, The Nation, and The
New Leader, a director of the
League for Industrial Democracy,
and a member of the executive committee of the American Civil Liberties Union.
Mr. Thomas is the author of The
Conscientious Objector in America,
Socialism of Our Times, What is
Industrial Democracy?, and several
other books on economic, political,
and social problems.

A rather unusual departure from
the regular routine will be made tonight at the regular weekly meeting of the Y. M. C. A. Cabinet,
when Sigmund Sonneborn, ex-Baltimore merchant, will give some
readings from his translations of
the Psalms in modern idiom.
Mr. Sonneborn recently read
some of his translations at a meeting called by Dr. John Dewey, professor of philosophy at Columbia
University, who is in favor of the
work being done by the exmerchant.
The time of the meeting has been
changed from 6.30 to 6 o'clock, in
order that it may be closed promptly
at 8.

If the respective merits of the
freshman and sophomores debaters
are to be considered as final, intercollegiate football should be abolished; for the frosh, taking the affirmative side of that question,
trounced the sophs at the regular assembly, yesterday.

Bang, freshmen, demanded a curtailment of the program of the national fall pastime on the grounds
that it had detrimental physical,
moral, and intellectual effects on
the student body of the college,
while the cause of intercollegiate
competition in football was defended by Fred Oken and Bernard

lost. Of course, when they are not
played fairly, that's another matter."
It was lunch time, and as both
campus leaders and reporters must
eat, the the interview was over.

UNION BUS TERMINAL

How to keep silt and sand from clogging telephone cable ducts was one problem put up to
engineers at Bell Telephone Laboratories. No
known method of joining sections of vitrified clay
conduit effected a seepage-tight joint.
With scientific thoroughness, telephone men
made many tests under service conditions. They
devised a bandage of cheese-cloth, waterproof
paper and mortar. Easily made and applied, this
mortar bandage is tight against silt and sand. It
prevents clogging, greatly simplifies the installation
of new telephone cables and the removal of old ones.
Through solving such interesting problems,
Bell System men work steadily nearer to their goal
— telephone service of highest possible efficiency.

Ice hockey plans for the coming
season at the Johns Hopkins will
be discussed today at the first organized meeting of the squad, to be
held at 12:20 in Room 120, Latrobe Hall. All members of the
team, both veterans and new candidates, are requested to be present.
Hopkins has entered the local ice
hockey league again, along with the
University of Maryland, Baltimore
Athletic Club, Mount Washington,
and Green Spring Valley. Walbrook, champions of the circuit last
year, will not defend its laurels.
Therefore, a wide-open battle is expected to develop among the contenders for possession of the title.

Successful Season Seen
After two weeks of diligent practice at the Knights of Columbus
pool, the Johns Hopkins University
swimming team will have its first
time trials this afternoon. The
trials will be held in the 50,
100, and 220-yard free style; the
100-yard breast stroke and 100yard back stroke and the fancy dive.
Several of the distances are shortened because of the lack of practice.
A successful season is anticipated as there is a wealth of
veteran material back from last
year's team, forming a powerful
nucleus for the present squad.
Record Breakers To Swim
The outlook in fancy diving is exceedingly bright as Captain William
Reid, indoor and outdoor South Atlantc diving champion, will again
compete for the University. Frank
Levi and Charles Bahlke, members
of last year's record-breaking relay,
will form the nucleus for this year's
quartet. Material for the breast
stroke is also abundant with Eddie
Sadtler and Ted Stern, who have
both broken former University
breast-stroke records, available for
the coming season. Nicholas Camara-Peon, a co-holder of the Hopkins backstroke record, and Ernie
Hanhart, last year's captain, are
other former performers who will
be with the team this year.
In addition to these, Gordon,
Bishop, Davis, and McConnell, who
have had previous experience, are
members of the present squad.

Although the Black and Blue did
not finish very high in last season's
race, it gained much needed experience which should prove extremely
valuable. The team probably will
receive its stiffest competition from
Maryland and Green Spring Valley.

JAY CAGERS
TO HOLD WORKOUTS
AT LOYOLA COLLEGE

Decide Definitely To Practice
And Play On Evergreen Court
After a week of steady practice,
staged temporarily at the Gilman
School gymnasium, the Johns Hopkins basketball team has made definite arrangements to make use of
the Loyola College gymnasium at
Evergreen for its practice sessions
and games during the 1932-1933
basketball season.
The Blue Jay cagers have been
holding workouts daily in which all
candidates have been receiving opportunities to show their playing
ability to Coach Darley.
Veterans Return

Among those showing promise at
the Black and Blue basketball drills
are Williamson, Lester and George
Margolis, Siverd, Yearley, Palitz,
Rapport, and Merriken.
The veterans who are back again
this season are Captain Don Kelly,
Caleb Kelly, Herb Camitta, Chancellor and Wulff.
The squad is still very small,
however, and all students interested
in playing basketball are urged to
report for practice.

(Continued from Page 1, Col. 6)
required to turn over to Pi Delta
Epsilon by Marih 22 the names of
nominees for the board of sontrol
posts for 1933-34. These men will
be considered at a meeting of the
honorary fraternity on March 24
and their merits will be openely discussed by the publication heads present. Should there be doubt as to
the capability of any nominee to
handle the position for which he is
nominated, it was said, the board
of control of the particular publication will be asked to reconsider the
candidate before elections are held
some time during the first two weeks
of April. It was pointed out that
an effort is to be made to weed out
those men who seek office for purely political reasons.
To Control Varsity Seal Awards

Holding to the belief that in the
past publications men have been
awarded Varsity Seals despite the
fact that they have failed to actually meet the requirement of three
years of work on the staff, Pi Delta
Epsilon will record the date of election to any staff of business and editorial candidates to THE NEWSLETTER, The Black and Blue Jay,
and The Hullabaloo, and will record any comments by publication
heads on the work done by staff
members. On the basis of this information Pi Delta Epsilon will recommend or reject eligibles for the
Varsity Seal award. In this way,
members said, those who do not deserve Seals will not be awarded
them.
A recommendation will be made
to the publications here to issue official identification cards to its staff
members and to include space on
these cards for the recording of the
date of election to the staff.
Tentative Date For Election

A tentative date, April 13, has
been set for the public annual initiation of men into the honorary fraternity. This date was chosen, it
was announced, because by that time
all editors and business managers
for 1933-34 will be chosen. The
Student Activities Council is to set
dates for all campus elections in the
first two weeks of April. It was said
that the heads of the three publications and outstanding members of
the staffs of the newspaper, magazine, and yearbook will be eligible
for election into Pi Delta Epsilon,
which has 40 chapters in colleges
throughout the United States.
At present there are eight men
in the Hopkins chapter, which was
reorganized in May, 1931, fife years
after its disbandment at Homewood. They are Charles Davis,
president; Morton Gutkin, secretary; Maurice Chassin, treasurer;
Hyman Levin, E. Gordon Biggs,
Gordon Green, Haskell Milestone,
and Morton Katz. They were
elected into the journalistic fraternity last April. Membership to the
J. H. U. chapter is restricted to
those who have been actively conhected with either THE NEWS-LETTER, The Black and Blue Jay, and

The Hullabaloo.
Mitchell, associate professor of political economy, is an honorary
member of the organization.

Noted Editor

After leaving the ministry several years ago, Mr. Thomas founded
and became the editor of The World

of The Nation. At present he is

other books on economic, political,

A rather unusual departure from
the regular routine will be made tonight at the regular weekly meeting of the Y. M. C. A. Cabinet,
when Sigmund Sonneborn, ex-Baltimore merchant, will give some
readings from his translations of
the Psalms in modern idiom.
Mr. Sonneborn recently read
some of his translations at a meeting called by Dr. John Dewey, professor of philosophy at Columbia
University, who is in favor of the
work being done by the exmerchant.
The time of the meeting has been
changed from 6.30 to 6 o'clock, in
order that it may be closed promptly
at 8.

freshman and sophomores debaters

Bang, freshmen, demanded a curtailment of the program of the national fall pastime on the grounds
that it had detrimental physical,
moral, and intellectual effects on
the student body of the college,
while the cause of intercollegiate
competition in football was defended by Fred Oken and Bernard
